main_point: The professor explains Network effects and platform lock-in and how to interpret evidence when measurements can be misleading.
detail1: The professor distinguishes price discrimination (a process) from elasticity (a proxy/measurement).
detail2: He suggests testing an asymmetric prediction involving incentive and network effect.
attitude: Casual but analytical; he warns against over-trusting a neat correlation.
organization_point: He adds a tangent about a lab mishap to show real-world constraints.
connecting_point: The example about controlling for hedging shows how bias can flip an apparent pattern.
